values.text: I'd be happy to recommend something. Do you have a favorite author or genre?
Let me know what kind of stories you enjoy — thrilling, emotional, magical?
Of course! Are you looking for a classic, a bestseller, or something new?
Sure! Are you in the mood for mystery, romance, fantasy, or something else?
Do you have a favorite genre or author in mind?
I can recommend books based on genre, mood, or author — what are you in the mood for?
Tell me your favorite genre or the last author you enjoyed — I’ll do the rest!
Let’s narrow it down — any genre or author you love?
What kind of story are you craving? Or is there an author you can’t get enough of?

Who’s an author you admire? Or shall I suggest by genre?
Need help picking a genre? I’ve got mystery, romance, fantasy, and more.
Genre guide? Author whisperer? I can be both. What’s your vibe?
Hit me with a genre or author — I’ll fetch the perfect read!
Hey, I’m Shelfie 📖 — your AI-powered book buddy! Let’s find your next favorite read. ✨
Welcome to Shelfie! 📚 The shelves are stacked, and the stories are waiting
Hi there, reader! I’m Shelfie — part chatbot, part bookshelf. Ready for a great recommendation?

Hey bookworm! 🐛 I’m Shelfie. Your digital bookshelf with personality. Ready to read something magical?

Brace yourself — King’s books don’t hold back. How scary are you willing to go?

No problem at all!
You're very welcome!📚
Always here if you need another good book!
Glad you liked the suggestion! Come back for more!
May the spine be strong and the plot even stronger. Catch you later!
Like a good book, I’ll be here waiting when you're ready to return

Come back anytime for a story tailored to your mood. See you!
May your bookmarks always find the best pages. See you soon!
Shelfie signing off — until your next story adventure!
Goodbye for now! May your next read be unputdownable

@genre is such a rich genre—there's always something brilliant to read!

Sorry, I couldn’t match that to my list. Want to browse genres or discover trending books instead?

Not everything has made it to my shelves yet — but I promise there’s still plenty of stories to discover!
Even digital shelves have limits... for now! But I’d still love to recommend something similar

Colleen Hoover never misses. Would you like a story about healing, heartbreak, or both?
Looks like I don’t have that one. But I can help with popular genres like fantasy, thriller, romance, or mystery!
That’s a rare request! While I can’t find it, I can offer books by mood, genre, or favorite authors. Want to give it another go?
Shelfie’s still expanding the library! Until then, how about a mystery, a classic, or a feel-good novel?

Classic whodunits and twist endings await! Do you want something iconic like Murder on the Orient Express or a lesser-known gem?
Nobody writes crime like Christie. Shall I serve up a chilling murder mystery?

Whether you’re 9 or 99, Harry Potter is always a good idea. Shall I bring the magic?

I’m Shelfie — your AI reading buddy! I can recommend books based on genre, mood, favorite authors, or even surprise you. 📚
Need a book that matches your vibe? Just tell me what you’re in the mood for — fantasy, romance, something spooky, or totally random!
You can say things like: ‘Suggest a mystery novel’, ‘Give me something happy’, or ‘I want a book by Dan Brown’.
Think of me as your magical bookshelf. Ask me for book recs by mood, genre, or even your favorite author. Need a classic? I got you!
Lost in the library? Just say: ‘Give me something thrilling’, ‘I want to cry-read’, or ‘Surprise me with a random book’
I’m here to spark your next story. Ask for a book by genre, mood, or author — or just say ‘Surprise me!’ for a random gem.
Shelfie is open! Ask for books that match your mood, explore new genres, or revisit your favorite author’s works

Not sure where to start? Try saying:
‘Give me a horror book’,
‘Suggest a classic’,
‘Show me something random’
From cozy reads to spine-tingling thrillers, I help you discover the perfect next book. Just tell me what you’re into today!

dialog_nodes.title: Summaries of books by dan brown

values.text: George Orwell’s writing is bold, thought-provoking, and timeless. Want dystopia like 1984 or political satire like Animal Farm?
Orwell’s classics hold chilling relevance today. Would you prefer totalitarian terror or allegorical animals?
Into rebellion and control? Orwell’s dystopias are a must-read. Want something intense or symbolic?
Students are being petrified at Hogwarts, and the legend of the Chamber of Secrets is revived. Harry discovers he can speak to snakes and ultimately defeats the basilisk to save Ginny Weasley.

dialog_nodes.conditions: @jk_rowling:(Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets)

values.text: Winston Smith lives under the oppressive regime of the Party and Big Brother, where independent thought is a crime. He begins a forbidden romance and keeps a diary, hoping for freedom. Eventually, he's caught, tortured, and brainwashed in the Ministry of Love until he truly loves Big Brother. It’s a powerful warning about surveillance, censorship, and totalitarianism.
The Da Vinci Code — Dan Brown
Angels & Demons — Dan Brown
Inferno — Dan Brown
The Lost Symbol — Dan Brown
Origin — Dan Brown
Verity — Colleen Hoover (romantic psychological thriller)
The Murder of Roger Ackroyd — Agatha Christie
The ABC Murders — Agatha Christie
And Then There Were None — Agatha Christie
Death on the Nile — Agatha Christie

Ten strangers are invited to a remote island by a mysterious host. One by one, they are killed in accordance with a nursery rhyme. As paranoia grows, they realize the murderer is among them—and no one is safe.

In the town of Derry, Maine, a shape-shifting entity that often appears as a clown named Pennywise awakens every 27 years to feed on children’s fear. A group of childhood friends confront the monster both as kids and later as adults, facing their deepest traumas. A sprawling tale of friendship, memory, and terror.
If you’re in the mood for love, loss, and messy emotions, CoHo’s got you. Want a contemporary romance or something darker like Verity?
Colleen Hoover never misses. Would you like a story about healing, heartbreak, or both?
Ready for an emotional rollercoaster? Colleen Hoover’s stories will break and rebuild your heart — how about It Ends With Us or Verity?

This book is split into two parts. The first documents Orwell’s investigation of poor working-class life in Northern England during the Great Depression. The second part is a fierce critique of British socialism and middle-class attitudes, exploring why socialism struggles to attract wider support.

This is Orwell’s personal account of his time fighting in the Spanish Civil War. He reflects on the chaos, betrayal, and idealism he witnessed, especially the internal conflict among leftist groups. It’s both a war memoir and political critique.

A nostalgic coming-of-age story set in 1960s Tokyo, this novel follows Toru Watanabe, a quiet college student, as he navigates love, loss, and emotional turmoil. Torn between two very different women — the emotionally fragile Naoko and the vibrant Midori — Toru grapples with the complexities of growing up and grieving.

Elizabeth Bennet, a witty and independent young woman, navigates love and social expectations in 19th-century England. When she meets the proud and wealthy Mr. Darcy, initial misunderstandings lead to conflict — and eventually, mutual respect and love. A timeless story of class, character, and courtship.

Sisters Elinor (practical) and Marianne (emotional) Dashwood must face love, heartbreak, and financial hardship after their father’s death leaves them nearly penniless. As they navigate the world of suitors and social pressures, the novel explores the balance between reason and feeling.

Jack Torrance, a struggling writer and recovering alcoholic, becomes the winter caretaker of the isolated Overlook Hotel. He moves in with his wife and young son, Danny, who has psychic abilities called "the shining." As supernatural forces possess Jack, the hotel turns into a terrifying trap. A chilling story of madness, addiction, and haunting evil.
oh good , let me give you some Agatha's work

When Toru Okada’s cat disappears, followed by his wife Kumiko, his mundane life unravels. His search leads him through Tokyo’s dark underbelly and his own subconscious. Mixing historical trauma with personal crisis, this novel is one of Murakami's most expansive, blending detective fiction, surrealism, and war memory.
Harry is unexpectedly entered into the dangerous Triwizard Tournament. He faces dragons, mermaids, and a maze, only to witness Voldemort’s return during the final task.

dialog_nodes.conditions: @jk_rowling:(Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire)

While vacationing in Egypt, Poirot investigates the murder of a wealthy heiress aboard a Nile cruise. Jealousy, betrayal, and a clever cover-up unfold in one of Christie’s most exotic mysteries.

Nobody "Bod" Owens is raised by ghosts in a graveyard after his family is murdered. As he grows, Bod learns life lessons from supernatural caretakers and faces dangers from both the living and the dead. A haunting, heartwarming coming-of-age tale inspired by The Jungle Book, set in a cemetery.

When Richard Mayhew helps a wounded girl on a London street, he becomes invisible to the world above and is pulled into “London Below” — a strange underground realm of forgotten people, monsters, and magic. A dark urban fantasy about finding one’s purpose and identity in the unlikeliest places.
Jane Austen serves wit, romance, and social commentary with grace. Ready for some Regency-era drama?
If you love clever heroines and charming conversations, Austen’s your match. Shall we start with Pride and Prejudice?
Looking for a timeless love story with a sharp tongue? Jane Austen always delivers.

As Voldemort gains power, Harry forms “Dumbledore’s Army” to fight back. He suffers loss and frustration as the Ministry denies the truth and Sirius Black dies in the battle at the Department of Mysteries.

dialog_nodes.conditions: @jk_rowling:(Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix)

values.text: Poirot receives taunting letters from a killer who murders victims in alphabetical order. With each crime scene linked by the ABC Railway Guide, Poirot must decipher the pattern to catch the criminal.

This surreal novel follows two intertwined stories: Kafka Tamura, a 15-year-old runaway fleeing from a dark prophecy, and Nakata, an elderly man who can speak to cats. Blending metaphysics, magic realism, and psychological themes, the novel explores identity, fate, and the subconscious.

Eight years after rejecting a marriage proposal from the earnest but poor Captain Wentworth, Anne Elliot is still unmarried and quietly regretful. When he re-enters her life — now successful and distant — Anne must navigate past choices, family influence, and her enduring feelings. A mature and emotional tale of second chances.
Harry discovers he is a wizard and attends Hogwarts. He learns of the Sorcerer’s Stone and confronts Professor Quirrell (possessed by Voldemort) who is trying to steal it.

A deadly virus wipes out most of humanity, and the survivors form two camps: one led by the kind-hearted Mother Abagail, the other by the evil Randall Flagg. As good and evil prepare for a final confrontation, the story explores morality, leadership, and survival. An epic post-apocalyptic saga of hope and horror.
Sirius Black escapes Azkaban. While everyone believes he’s after Harry, the truth reveals a betrayal by Peter Pettigrew—and Sirius is actually Harry’s godfather

dialog_nodes.conditions: @jk_rowling:(Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban)

values.text: A group of farm animals rebel against their human farmer, hoping to create an equal society. Over time, the pigs take control, and the farm becomes a dictatorship under Napoleon the pig. The famous line “All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others” shows how power corrupts. It's an allegory of the Russian Revolution and Stalin’s rise.
Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone — J.K. Rowling
Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets — J.K. Rowling
Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban — J.K. Rowling
Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire — J.K. Rowling
Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix — J.K. Rowling
Norwegian Wood — Haruki Murakami (older YA / coming-of-age)
Coraline — Neil Gaiman
The Graveyard Book — Neil Gaiman

Poirot retires to a village, only to be pulled into the suspicious murder of Roger Ackroyd. The shocking twist: the narrator of the story is the killer, challenging readers’ trust in storytelling itself.

The apocalypse is near, but the angel Aziraphale and demon Crowley — who've grown fond of Earth — team up to stop it. Meanwhile, the Antichrist is misplaced. A comedic and philosophical satire about fate, free will, and humanity, blending humor with a surprisingly heartfelt message.
Ah, the wizarding world! Are you starting the Harry Potter series, or would you like to explore her detective fiction under Robert Galbraith?
“J.K. Rowling’s magic isn’t just for Hogwarts. Want to dive into mystery with The Cuckoo’s Calling?
Whether you’re 9 or 99, Harry Potter is always a good idea. Shall I bring the magic?

Looking for something poetic and meaningful? Coelho’s stories are full of wisdom and wanderlust.
Whether you're seeking purpose or peace, Coelho’s got your back. Want something spiritual or philosophical?
Norwegian Wood
Kafka on the Shore
Colorless Tsukuru Tazaki and His Years of Pilgrimage
The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle

Hercule Poirot investigates the murder of a wealthy passenger aboard the Orient Express. As he interviews each traveler, he discovers they all had a motive—and were all involved in a collective act of justice for a past crime.

sukuru, once abandoned by his close group of high school friends without explanation, revisits his past to uncover the truth and heal. A quiet, introspective novel about friendship, alienation, and the longing for connection, it reflects on how unresolved emotional pain shapes adult identity.

dialog_nodes.conditions: @Haruki_murakami:(Colorless Tsukuru Tazaki and His Years of Pilgrimage)

values.text: Catherine Morland, a naïve and imaginative young woman, visits Bath and later the mysterious Northanger Abbey. Obsessed with gothic novels, she begins to confuse fiction with reality. The story humorously critiques romantic fantasies and traces Catherine’s journey toward self-growth and romantic maturity.

When Shadow Moon is released from prison, he is recruited by the mysterious Mr. Wednesday for a journey across America. Shadow soon learns he's caught in a war between the old gods (mythical deities) and the new (technology, media). A mythic, surreal exploration of belief, identity, and power in modern life.

Orwell describes his experiences living in poverty—first as a dishwasher in Paris, then homeless in London. It's a semi-autobiographical exploration of survival, class, and dignity among society’s most marginalized.

dialog_nodes.conditions: @george_orwell:(Down and Out in Paris and London)

values.text: Emma Woodhouse is charming, rich, and determined to play matchmaker in her social circle — despite lacking insight into her own heart. As her meddling leads to misunderstandings, she slowly learns humility, self-awareness, and eventually discovers true love where she least expected it.

Young Coraline discovers a hidden door in her family's new home that leads to a mirrored world — similar to her own, but darkly twisted. Her "Other Mother" offers her everything she wants... at a sinister cost. A modern dark fairy tale about bravery, choice, and being careful what you wish for.

Carrie White, a shy, bullied teenager with a religiously fanatical mother, discovers she has telekinetic powers. After a cruel prank at prom pushes her over the edge, she unleashes devastating vengeance on her town. A tragic and powerful debut novel about bullying, repression, and the consequences of cruelty.

Famous author Paul Sheldon is rescued from a car crash by Annie Wilkes, his “number one fan.” But Annie turns out to be dangerously unstable — and she’s furious that Paul killed off her favorite character. Trapped in her remote home, Paul is forced to write a new novel under threat of torture. A psychological horror about obsession and creative imprisonment.
